header.title: The Sacred Magician: A Ceremonial Diary
header.category: Western Esotericism, Ceremonial Magic, Spiritual Diary

central_thesis: This book is William Bloom's detailed diary of his six-month performance of 'The Sacred Magic of Abramelin the Mage,' a rigorous ceremonial magic ritual aimed at achieving communication with his Holy Guardian Angel and subsequently controlling evil spirits. The central thesis explores the profound personal, psychological, and spiritual transformation experienced during this intense undertaking, highlighting a dualistic approach that integrates both a psychological interpretation of archetypal forms and a full commitment to the reality of spiritual entities.

structure_content.summary: Bloom describes his background as a publisher and novelist, his three years of intense reading in mystical and occult literature, and his motivation for undertaking the Abramelin ritual at age twenty-six. He outlines his dualistic perspective on the ritual (psychological exploration of self/shadow vs. interaction with real spiritual entities) and the physical preparations made in Morocco. He also reflects on the influence of two older men (James Baldwin and Edward Glover) and the support of his partner, Frances.

structure_content.chapter_title: Facsimile of The Book of the Sacred Magic
structure_content.summary: This section reproduces key instructions from S.L. MacGregor Mathers' 1900 translation of 'The Book of the Sacred Magic of Abramelin the Mage.' It details the requirements for the six-month operation, including daily prayers, purity, seclusion, dietary restrictions, preparation of ritual objects (oratory, altar, robes, oil, incense, wand), and the procedures for the convocation of good and evil spirits.

Diary entries from March 20 to May 20, 1973, detailing the initial phase of the ritual. Bloom recounts daily prayers, encounters with malevolent energies, physical manifestations (head spinning, energy rushes), and early spiritual insights. He explores themes of worthiness, sinfulness, and the struggle to maintain discipline. Noteworthy events include his self-marriage with Frances, healing exercises, out-of-body experiences, and an intense 'psychic attack' involving 'evil negative electric charge' and a vision of Adolf Hitler.

Diary entries from May 21 to July 20, detailing the middle phase of the ritual. Bloom describes continued battles with malevolent energies, physical illness, and personal struggles. He delves deeper into psychological concepts (e.g., 'Dark Night of the Soul,' 'personality as a neutral body'), integrates teachings from Alice Bailey and the Zohar, and explores the duality within himself (personality vs. soul/monad). He records a vision of the Tibetan teacher Djwahl Khul coming to assist Frances and a sense of 'super-surge of white-light' energy.

Diary entries from July 21 to September 20, covering the final preparation for the climax. This period is marked by intense duality, internal 'warfare,' severe physical and emotional strain, and a deeper understanding of the ritual's purpose. Bloom describes the importance of continuous meditation, battling distractions, and the experience of kundalini energy. He contemplates the role of his 'personality' versus his 'soul' and 'monad,' and expresses both despair and moments of profound bliss and connection to divine grace, ultimately focusing on purity and devotion.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Seven Days of Consecration, Convocation and Conjuration
structure_content.summary: A detailed account of the final, climactic seven-day period from September 21 to 27. Bloom describes the consecration process, including washing, robing, anointing, and fervent prayer. He recounts the 'full and complete conversation' with his Holy Guardian Angel, the summoning and obtaining oaths from the Four Superior Princes (Lucifer, Leviathan, Satan, Belial) and Eight Sub-Princes (Astaroth, Magoth, Asmodeus, Beelzebuth, Oriens, Paimon, Ariton, Amaymon). He notes the physical and psychic effects of these powerful evocations, including intense energy flows, skull pressure, and lessons on spiritual control and conduct.

Bloom reflects on the immediate aftermath of the ritual, describing his inability to reflect due to intense psychic and emotional 'throbbing.' He details a two-year period of severe illness (Hepatitis-B) that followed, which he later understood as a necessary healing and integration process for his 'psychic explosion' and 'storming heaven pattern.' Twenty years later, he outlines the long-term integration process, which included parenting, meditation, academic study, and teaching. He emphasizes that magical powers never interested him, only the transformative discipline, and encourages a careful approach to the Abramelin ritual.

A comprehensive list of books referenced in the diary, indicating the author's extensive reading in various esoteric and spiritual traditions, including Alice Bailey, S.L. MacGregor Mathers, Mouni Sadhu, Israel Regardie, and the I Ching.

key_concepts.term: The Sacred Magic of Abramelin the Mage (Operation)
key_concepts.definition: A six-month ceremonial magic ritual, as detailed in the grimoire, that involves intense purification, prayer, and solitude, culminating in a seven-day period of consecration, convocation, and conjuration. Its primary aim is to achieve conversation with the Holy Guardian Angel and then to bind evil spirits.

The central entity invoked in the Abramelin ritual. Bloom interprets it dualistically as both a metaphor for the individual's 'core true self' or 'eternal essence' and as a real angelic entity that serves as a guide and offers protection and wisdom. Communication with the HGA is the first goal of the ritual.

Interpreted by Bloom as both 'shadow aspects of my own psyche' that are normally unencountered and as 'real angels and real demons' that are summoned and subjected to the magician's will after communion with the HGA. The ritual aims to constrain them and make them pledge obedience.

The consecrated space, often a small chapel or room with a window and terrace, where the daily prayers and ritual actions are performed. It requires specific preparation, including an altar, oil lamp, charcoal incense burner, and river sand.

Bloom's method of engaging with the ritual, simultaneously approaching it from a 'psychological perspective' (as an exploration of the collective unconscious and archetypal forms) and 'with the full commitment of a devoted mystic' (as an interaction with genuine spiritual realities).

The spiritual path is understood as a series of initiations, each marking a 'new expansion in consciousness and a greater surrender to Love.' The Abramelin ritual itself is described as a 'sacred drama' and 'burning ground of initiation' leading to higher levels of spiritual awareness.

A subtle energy, often described in Eastern traditions, which Bloom experiences as 'rising from the base of the spine to the head centre,' associated with achieving 'full psychism and third-eye vision.' Its uncontrolled flow can lead to intense physical sensations and psychological stress.

A mystical state of spiritual aridity, confusion, and despair, characterized by the feeling that 'all the powers of the soul seem dead.' Bloom recognizes his own periods of intense psychological and spiritual struggle within this framework.

In the context of esoteric Buddhism and Theosophy (referenced by Bloom), the pure cosmic spirit or over-soul, distinct from the personality and personal soul. Achieving contact or 'monadic awareness' is described as a laser beam of ecstasy opening into infinity.

Bloom's concept, developed from his experiences, that human ecological responsibility extends to purifying 'emotions and thoughts' to avoid 'polluting the atmosphere' with negative energies. It highlights the workability of the 'Great Arcanum' (magical method of effecting physical changes psychically).

practical_system.description: The practical system is the Abramelin Operation, a six-month intensive ceremonial magic ritual divided into three two-month phases, culminating in a seven-day period of consecration and conjuration. The core principle is purification and devotion to God to achieve communication with the Holy Guardian Angel, followed by the subjugation of evil spirits. It emphasizes solitude, purity, strict adherence to prayers, and the careful preparation and use of ritual tools.
tools: Oratory (small chapel, undisturbed, with a window)
Altar (hollow, made of wood or unhewn stones)
Oil Lamp (suspended above altar, burning olive oil)
River Sand (covering the terrace outside the Oratory, two fingers deep)
Special Robes (two sets: White Tunic of linen; Crimson/Scarlet Silk with Gold for later phases)
Crown or Mitre (woven Silk and Gold fillet)
Wand (Almond-tree wood, smooth and straight, half an ell to six feet)
Holy Oil (made from Myrrh, Cinnamon, Galangal, Oil Olive)
Perfume (made from Incense, Stacte, Lign Aloes or cedar/rose/citron wood)
Small Square Plate of Silver (for the HGA to write a sign)
rituals: Daily prayers (morning during first two months, morning/evening during middle two months, thrice daily during last two months and final seven days)
Confession of sins with humility and fervour
Supplication for divine grace and the sending of the Holy Guardian Angel
Washing the entire body and putting on clean clothing (especially on Sabbath eve)
Fasting (Qabalistical fast every Sabbath eve during the middle two months, carrots and bread during Easter, three days before putting the Operation to work)
Consecration of ritual tools (robes, crown, girdle, wand, holy oil, perfume, censer)
Invocation of the Lord and Holy Guardian Angels
Conjuration of the Four Superior Princes and Eight Sub-Princes (on specific days during the final seven days), compelling them to swear oaths of obedience

relevant_quotes.text: When I committed myself to this six month ritual my attitude was dualistic. On one side I approached it purely from a psychological perspective. On the other I approached it with the full commitment of a devoted mystic. I thought that I was about to explore two landscapes.
The climax of this ritual is 'full communication with your Holy Guardian Angel' and then the summoning and controlling of the world of demonic entities.
I was an intense, aggressive and confused psyche, and only the kind of power which he indeed delivered could touch me.

My body quivered from an evil negative electric charge from them and I lost total control. My body in pain from their negative electricity, I was picked up and manoeuvred like a paper doll, completely at their whim. I was totally and vulnerably powerless.
The strain is holding that meditation; the strain is not holding it; it is all strain â€“ but deserved, and shortly I shall increase the pressure as much as I can.

I had full and complete conversation with this great angelic being and consciousness. So what had happened to me in the Oratory? When this diary was originally published in 1976, I did not write an explanation of what had happened in the Oratory.

What a wonderful and extraordinary illness it was. How carefully my own soul or my Teacher must have planned it. Twenty years later I can still think of no more efficient or economic way of integrating my energies. How else could I have calmed my psychic explosion and transformed my storming heaven pattern?

critical_analysis.relevance: Bloom's diary is a highly relevant contribution to the study of Western Esotericism and occultism, offering a rare first-person account of the 'Abramelin Operation,' a ritual traditionally veiled in secrecy. Its candid descriptions of the psychological, emotional, and physical challenges demystify aspects of intense magical practice, providing a raw and honest counterpoint to theoretical texts. By integrating Jungian psychological interpretations with a mystic's faith in spiritual realities, Bloom offers a nuanced perspective on the 'inner' and 'outer' dimensions of magical work, making the ancient grimoire tradition accessible to contemporary understanding. His post-ritual reflections on the integration process and the unexpected 'healing crisis' (Hepatitis-B) underscore the transformative, and often arduous, nature of deep esoteric work, distinguishing it from superficial magical pursuits. The book serves as a cautionary tale and a guide, emphasizing self-discipline, inner purity, and the dangers of ego in magical practice.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes serious students and practitioners of Western Esotericism, Ceremonial Magic, and Grimoire Traditions, particularly those interested in the 'Abramelin Operation.' It also appeals to scholars of religious studies, transpersonal psychology, and consciousness studies, offering rich empirical data for understanding altered states and spiritual experiences. Psychologists, especially those with a Jungian orientation, would find value in Bloom's introspective analysis of the psyche's role. Finally, individuals on a path of intensive spiritual development or self-transformation, seeking insights into the challenges and rewards of such journeys, would find the diary compelling, albeit with Bloom's strong caveats about careful preparation and suitability.
